questions.question: Otoendoscopy of a patient revealed cholesteatoma limited to the protympanum. Which of the following sites is being referred to here?

options.A: The developmental predecessor of the middle ear
options.B: The anterior part of the middle ear
options.C: The part of the middle ear foremost in conduction of sound
options.D: The part of the middle ear around the Eustachian tube

questions.explanation: The protympanum refers to the anterior part of the middle ear.

questions.question: Which is the narrowest part of the middle ear?
questions.explanation: Mesotympanum is the narrowest part of the middle ear. Transverse diameters of the middle ear at various levels are: Epitympanum - 6 mm, Mesotympanum - 2 mm, Hypotympanum - 4 mm. Divisions of the middle ear: lateral attic wall, Pars flaccida, Pars tensa. The narrowest part is between Epitympanum and Mesotympanum and Hypotympanum.

questions.question: What is the distance between the promontory and the tympanic membrane?
questions.explanation: The distance between the promontory and the tympanic membrane, i.e., the transverse diameter at the level of the mesotympanum, is 2 mm.

questions.question: In a patient with necrotizing otitis media, CT scans reveal erosions of the structures present in the epitympanum. Which of the following is least likely to be involved?
questions.explanation: Footplate of stapes is least likely to be involved in the given scenario because it is not a part of the epitympanum. Epitympanum contains: • Head of the malleus • Incudomalleolar joint • Short process and body of the incus. Divisions of the middle ear: Lateral attic wall, Pars flaccida, Pars tensa, Epitympanum, Mesotympanum, Hypotympanum

questions.question: While performing tympanoplasty, the ENT surgeon notices that the floor of the middle ear is deficient. Which of the following structures is susceptible to injury?
questions.explanation: The internal jugular vein is susceptible to injury in this given clinical scenario. The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane, making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery. The middle ear can be likened to a room with a roof, floor, and 4 walls (anterior, posterior, medial, and lateral), as shown in the image: Boundaries of the middle ear, Prominence of facial canal, Prominence of lateral semi-circular canal, Tegmen tympani, Promontory, Aditus to mastoid antrum, Oval window, Pyramidale eminence, Chorda tympani nerve, Facial nerve (VII), Round window.

questions.question: Which part of the middle ear is formed by the tegmen tympani?

options.C: Lateral wall of the middle ear
options.D: Medial wall of the middle ear

questions.explanation: The internal jugular vein, tensor tympani muscle, pharyngotympanic tube, lesser petrosal nerve, sympathetic plexus, internal carotid artery, chorda tympani nerve, branch from internal carotid plexus, and tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) are all related to the middle ear. The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as the tegmen mastoidea.

questions.question: CT scans of a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma reveal that the tumor has undergone local spread, destroying the anterior wall of the middle ear. Which of the following structures is least likely to be involved?
questions.explanation: The prominence of the facial canal is least likely to be injured in this given clinical scenario because it is a part of the medial wall of the middle ear and not the anterior wall. The anterior wall of the middle ear is related to the following structures: the Eustachian tube, the canal for tensor tympani, and the internal carotid artery. Boundaries of the middle ear include the prominence of facial canal, prominence of lateral semi-circular canal, tegmen tympani, promontory, aditus to mastoid antrum, oval window, pyramidal eminence, chorda tympani nerve, facial nerve (VII), round window, internal jugular vein, tensor tympani muscle, pharyngotympanic tube, lesser petrosal nerve, sympathetic plexus, internal carotid artery, chorda tympani nerve, branch from internal carotid plexus, tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX).

questions.question: Which of the following structures is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear?
questions.explanation: The subiculum is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear. It is present in the medial wall, below the sinus tympani. The lateral wall of the middle ear separates it from the external ear. It contains: • Pars tensa lying opposite to the mesotympanum • Pars flaccida and scutum lying opposite to the epitympanum. Scutum or lateral attic wall is a wedge-shaped bone that separates the epitympanum from the external auditory canal. It can be eroded in attic cholesteatomas. Image showing the boundaries of middle ear: Tegmen tympani Lateral malleolar fold Outer attic wall/scutum Pars flaccida Lateral process Pars tensa Umbo Boundaries of the middle ear Middle cranial fossa - Promontory

questions.question: Which of the following structures is not related to the pyramid?
questions.explanation: The round window is not related to the pyramid because it is a medial wall structure, whereas the pyramid is a projection present in the posterior wall. Image showing pyramidal eminence: The facial recess and sinus tympani, Chorda tympani - Facial recess, VII Nerve, Pyramid, Sinus tympani. The pyramid has the following features: It contains the stapedius muscle, and the tendon leaves the pyramid to attach to the neck of the stapes. It divides the posterior space into a medial sinus tympani and a lateral facial recess. It serves as the landmark for the second genu of the facial nerve and houses the vertical segment of the facial nerve and the nerve to stapedius. The aditus (opening to the mastoid) lies just above it. Boundaries of the middle ear: Prominence of facial canal, Prominence of lateral semi-circular canal. Aditus to mastoid antrum, Oval window. Pyramidal eminence, Chorda tympani nerve, Facial nerve (VII), Round window, Internal jugular vein, Tegmen tympani, Promontory, Tensor tympani muscle, Pharyngotympanic tube, Lesser petrosal nerve, Sympathetic plexus, Internal Carotid artery, Chorda tympani nerve, Branch from internal carotid plexus, Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX)

questions.question: You are approaching the middle ear via the mastoid through the facial recess. Regarding anatomical relations of the facial recess, which of the following is true?

options.A: Bound medially by the horizontal part of the facial nerve
options.B: Bound laterally by the chorda tympani
options.C: Bound superiorly by the chordal ridge
options.D: Bound inferiorly by the fossa incudis

questions.explanation: Facial recess or the posterior sinus is a depression in the posterior wall, lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the facial nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani, and above by the fossa incudis. Facial recess is important surgically, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall. This is called the intact canal wall technique.

questions.question: A child with cholesteatoma undergoes surgical removal via an intact canal wall procedure. Through which of the following structures is the middle ear approached?
questions.explanation: In intact canal wall surgeries, the middle ear is approached through the suprapyramidal recess. Surgically, facial recess/posterior sinus/supra pyramidal recess is important, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall (intact canal wall technique). Image showing the facial recess: The facial recess and sinus tympani Chorda tympani - Facial recess VII Nerve Pyramid Sinus tympani OM ARROW

questions.question: Which of the following structures forms the promontory?
questions.explanation: The basal turn of the cochlea forms the promontory. The promontory is a bulge in the middle ear's medial wall, which is formed by the labyrinth. It gives two extensions: the subiculum below to the round window, and the ponticulus to the posterior wall.

questions.question: Which is the smallest bone in the body?
questions.explanation: The smallest bone in the body is the stapes. It is also called a stirrup as it looks like the stirrup/footrest for jockeys while riding a horse. The malleus is called the hammer. The incus is called the anvil (large metal striking surface for shaping metals).

questions.question: What is the type of joint between the middle ear ossicles?
questions.explanation: The type of joint between the middle ear ossicles is the synovial joint. The malleo-incudal joint is a saddle type. The incudostapedial joint is a ball-and-socket type.

questions.question: What is the structure marked in the given image?
questions.explanation: The marked structure is the incus. This is an image taken during a mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes. CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicircular canal; M: malleus; PSC: posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following is attached to the fossa incudis?
questions.explanation: Fossa incudis gives attachment to the short process of the incus. Fossa incudis is a depression on the posterior wall of the middle ear. It lies lateral to the aditus ad antrum.

questions.question: Which among the following structures covers the oval window?
questions.explanation: The oval window is covered by the footplate of stapes. Stabilizing ligaments, External acoustic meatus, Tympanic membrane, Middle ear, Tympanic cavity, Auditory ossicles: Malleus, Incus, Stapes, Oval window, Round window, Auditory tube

questions.question: Which of the following structures vibrates when the stapes footplate is moved?
questions.explanation: The movement of the stapes footplate causes vibration in the scala vestibuli. This is because the scala vestibuli, which opens at the oval window, is closed by the footplate of the stapes. The scala tympani opens at the round window. Image depicting the transmission of sound: Transmission of sound - Malleus, Incus, Stapes, Scala vestibuli, Oval window, External Tympanic acoustic meatus membrane, Scala tympani, Round window, Marrow.

questions.question: Which of the following covers the round window?
questions.explanation: The round window, or the fenestra cochlea, is covered by the secondary tympanic membrane.

questions.question: Which of the following is related to the processus cochleariformis?
questions.explanation: Processus cochleariformis is related to the tendon of tensor tympani. Just anterior to the oval window, the medial wall presents a hook-like projection called the processus cochleariformis. The tendon of tensor tympani takes a turn here to get attachment to the neck of the malleus. It is also the landmark for the 1st genu of the facial nerve and the geniculate ganglion. Processus cochleariformis and its relations: Geniculate ganglion - First genu of facial nerve, Facial nerve, Processus cochleariformis - Tendon of tensor tympani.

questions.question: Impedance audiometry performed in a patient showed an absent stapedial reflex. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?

options.B: Anterior division of the mandibular nerve
options.C: Posterior division of the mandibular nerve

questions.explanation: The absence of stapedial reflex is suggestive of facial nerve injury among the given options. The facial nerve forms the efferent arm of the stapedial or acoustic reflex. Anatomy of the stapedius muscle: The stapedius is a second-arch muscle and it arises from the pyramid and attaches to the neck of the stapes. Its action is to lateralize the stapes and dampen loud sounds. It is supplied by a branch of the facial nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following nerves supply the tensor tympani?

options.B: Branch from the medial pterygoid nerve

questions.explanation: Tensor tympani is supplied by a branch from the medial pterygoid nerve, which is a direct branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (and not the posterior division of the mandibular nerve). Anatomical features of the tensor tympani muscle: The tensor tympani develops from the first arch. It arises from the semicanal for tensor tympani in the anterior wall of the middle ear. It hooks around the processus cochleariformis in the medial wall and attaches to the neck of the malleus in the lateral wall. Its action is to medialize the malleus and conduct sound. The posterior division of the mandibular nerve is mainly sensory and divides into three branches: the auriculotemporal nerve, the lingual nerve, and the inferior alveolar (dental) nerve. The motor component of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve supplies the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric.

questions.question: Which of the following cranial nerves provide sensory supply to the middle ear cavity?
questions.explanation: The sensory supply to the middle ear cavity is provided by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. It forms the tympanic plexus with the caroticotympanic nerves from the internal carotid plexus of the sympathetic fibers. Boundaries of the middle ear: Prominence of facial canal, Prominence of lateral semi-circular canal, Tegmental tympani, Promontory, Tensor tympani muscle. Adults to mastoid antrum: Oval window, Pyramidal eminence, Chorda tympani nerve, Facial nerve (VII), Round window, Internal jugular vein, Pharyngotympanic tube, Lesser petrosal nerve, Sympathetic plexus, Internal Carotid artery, Chorda tympani nerve, Branch from internal carotid plexus, Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX).

questions.question: Which of the following nerves does not contribute to the tympanic plexus?
questions.explanation: The tympanic branch of the facial nerve does not contribute to the tympanic plexus. The tympanic plexus is formed by three nerves: the glossopharyngeal nerve forms the tympanic branch, and the sympathetic fibers from the internal carotid plexus form the superior and inferior caroticotympanic nerves. The tympanic plexus innervates the tympanic membrane's medial surface, the tympanic cavity, mastoid air cells, and the bony Eustachian tube. It also carries secretory fibers for the parotid gland, and in Frey's syndrome, the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve can be sectioned.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the facial nerve course in the middle ear?

options.A: Horizontal in the medial wall, vertical in the posterior wall
options.B: Vertical in the medial wall, horizontal in the posterior wall
options.C: Horizontal in the medial wall, vertical in the anterior wall
options.D: Vertical in the medial wall, horizontal in the anterior wall

questions.explanation: The facial nerve runs horizontally in the medial wall and vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear. The medial wall is related to the 3rd part, which runs from the 1st genu (processus cochleariformis) to the 2nd genu (pyramid). It is called the tympanic or horizontal part. The posterior wall is related to the 4th part, which runs from the genu (pyramid) to the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone. It is called the mastoid or the vertical part. Image showing course of facial nerve in ear: Facial nerve in the temporal bone - Horizontal segment in medial wall - Facial nerve (VII) - Vertical segment in posterior wall - Arrow: Internal acoustic meatus

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the course of the chorda tympani in the middle ear?

options.B: Enters the middle ear lateral to the tympanic membrane
options.C: Runs between the malleus and incus
options.D: Enters the middle ear via the canal of Huguier

questions.explanation: In the middle ear, the chorda tympani runs between the malleus and incus. Image showing the course of the chorda tympani: Chorda tympani in the temporal bone, malleus, tympanic membrane, incus.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the lesser petrosal nerve?

options.A: It is formed over the promontory of the middle ear
options.B: It is a branch of the tympanic plexus
options.D: Its fibers synapse in the pterygopalatine ganglion

questions.explanation: The fibers of the lesser petrosal nerve synapse in the otic ganglion and not the pterygopalatine ganglion. The lesser petrosal nerve is the parasympathetic or secretomotor nerve for the parotid glands. It arises over the promontory of the middle ear from the tympanic plexus (glossopharyngeal nerve). Image showing lesser petrosal nerve synapsing with otic ganglion: Otic ganglion, Tympanic plexus, Glossopharyngeal nerve, Lesser petrosal nerve, Parotid branches of auriculotemporal nerve, Otic ganglion, Tympanic nerve. Parotid gland
